When we ask "what is the fastest way for something to travel in the universe" withought specifying who is making the observation, we ask an incomplete question.

Infact there are 2 questions that we can ask:

1) "what is the fastest way for something to travel in the universe from our perspective"
2) ""what is the fastest way for something to travel in the universe from its own perspective"

Also, when we ask that question we never care about the passage of time... So the actual questions should be"

1 but better) "what is the fastest way for something to travel in the universe from our perspective regardless of how much time its clock shows"
2 but better) "what is the fastest way for something to travel in the universe from its own perspective regardless of how much time our clock shows"

And that has 2 answers:

1) C = 1ls/s or "the speed of light"
2) Infinity = ∞

Explanation:

C = 1ls/s (1 lightsecond per second) is the speed of C or the speed of causality. But it will be that number ONLY if whoever measures it, IS NOT, the one traveling at that speed! If I'm traveling at C and try to measure my speed, I won't find it to be C! I will find it to be infinity! Because from my perspective, time doesn't tic, therefore I can reach any distance at zero time, which MEANS, that my speed is infinite (from my perspective...). But if Im not the one doing the measurement, then my speed is indeed C = 1ls/s.

So we can't just ask, "how fast can something go in the Universe?" withought specifying who's making the measurement... Because there are 2 equally valid and equally true answers that are not the same (or... they are the same, but most people don't know that).

So infact, if you want to reach any point in space at zero time, if you want to travel at infinite speed, then all you need to do, is reach the speed of 1ls/s and thats enough! Time for you will slow down completely and you will reach any point in space at zero time...

So saying that "there is a speed limit in the universe" is missleading...

There is a speed limit in the spacetime. That's C=1ls/s. But if we only care about space or time, then in just space or in just time, there is no speed limit from the perspective of the traveler.

I am horrified by how much in this video is just wrong. Whoever wrote this script knows nothing about light and if they have a physics degree they should return it.

Light isn't 'the smallest quantity of energy that can be transported'. I think this is meant to be something about quantisation, but particles are quantised. (The smallest amount of energy is the Plank energy.) Light is a wave/particle which is a 'disturbance' in an EM field.

Visible light is NOT the only type of light that can propogate easily through water (if it was x-rays could not penetrate the water in your cells). We evolved to see in the visible because that's where the Sun produces most of its light (and some creatures can see in the near UV and IR).

We DO know why light has the speed it does - it is due to the permitivity of free space (or whatever medium it is travelling through). We have known this for over 150 years (and electromagnetism was one of the great advances in modern physics). That whoever wrote this thinks this is mysterious speaks volumes about their physics knowledge.

If you have any shame you will take this video down and fire whoever wrote it. There are millions of views from people who trust that you aren't talking garbage in your videos. (BTW I am qualified to say this as a professor of theoretical physics.)

Suggestions for improvement:
I suggest green be shown in the visible light spectrum
I suggest if you use a cent as a reference you say ‘US cent’ if that’s what it is. However as an Australian I have no idea how big that is, so why not choose something more international?
It would be worth mentioning that the retina has the ability to absorb photons - that is how we see.

What is common about all electromagnetic waves? .... They all behave as wave

I'm gonna answer it for you:

Light is cool

My favorite fun fact about light is that just how there is a multimillion year delay in when a star creates light and it reaches our eyes in a way we can look back in time. This also means if we were able to somehow travel far enough away in the universe, we could look back at Earth and see dinosaurs and wouldn't it be neat?

Of course there is also a problem. As light leaves it spreads out wider and wider. This means that you need a larger and larger lens to capture all the light which has spread.

And I read somewhere that if it was possible to create a telescope lenses larger enough to capture all that spread out light, it's mass would be so huge it would immediately collapse into a black hole.

So we can only imagine it. Too bad. Still, kinda neat to think about. We could still look back in time, just not quite that far. Did you ever want to witness a specific historic event in recent history? (If by "recent" you means tens of thousands of years ago.)

The electromagnetic wave is a stream of photons orbiting a common line of transit. We measure it in two ways. One by the diameter of the wave and the second is by its frequency over a distance of 186282.38 miles in one seconds worth of our time momentum value. On Earth we have discovered that the two factors have a singular relationship in that if we know one, we know the other value. This poses a problem when yo get to great distances from Earth, because the wave diameter received on our receptors from very distant objects do not comply with our formula for wave length and frequency criteria.. The simplistic explanation is that a wave travels through the gravitational force of its universe at all times while it is in transit. The force of gravity operates on all masses at a ratio of four to two. While we have not determined the mass of a photon, the universe has no such constraints. It is incredibly small and it takes a great distance for the universal gravity to distort the wave diameter over specific distances in a ratio of four times its distance of travel from its source to doubling its distortion rate by a factor of two.

I think light behaves as the wave-particle duality, because it travels outside of our observable time frame.
Due to physical limitations, observers can only observe things that have already happened. By the time they detect something, it has already happened in the past.
Light, on the other hand, moves so fast that it's always at the present moment as things happen in the linear time and physical space.
Basically, light will always move slightly faster than a physical observation, so it seems to exist all over the place as a wave of probabilities until it has finally been observed, at which point the light has already become a part of the past(time frame we can observe) as a particle, or an information of a fixed position of light that has been observed in this particular space-time.
Looking at it that way, light perhaps exists at the borderline between matter with mass and non-matter.
C, the speed of light, would most likely be the maximum frame rate of the material universe, because it exists right on the speed limit. Anything slower than light would produce mass(a fixed position in space-time which is perhaps what creates gravity), and anything faster would probably leave our linear time frame and become unobservable by direct physical means.
Meaning light would appear as a wave of probabilities the moment before we detect it due to light being outside of our fixed space-time, and it would appear as a particle after we do observe it and it becomes a part of the past. But it only appears as wave-particle from our linear time perspective for both cases.
It is quite possible that light exists as some other state above the C barrier, but we're only able to see it as light in the physical universe, the same way 2D beings would only be able to see flat shapes when looking at 3D beings.

This is wrong. Light is unique. Imagine it like a round ball, The low frequencies and high frequencies are at the center, High frequencies towards the surface of the ball. Think of light as like a liquid rippling when it hits something, when light hits things with other frequencies such as sound waves or gravity waves it vibrates, This is why people think its a wave, Its actually lights reaction to hitting something else, The other thing ripples and light bounces on the wave, That is why it ripples or shimmers in the double slit, Similar to pilot wave theory, or interference waves where you bounce 2 balls on water. Here light is the 2 balls,  The water waves are gravity waves, So Gravity(or whatever) interference waves frequencies decides the direction the high light frequencies ripple out from, The center of the light goes straight but it is rippling when it hits gravity waves.  Everyone is wrong, Einstein was more actually right, The world is deterministic, There is no wave/particle duality, Light is neither. Light is light,  Light a round ball with all frequencies at the center and higher frequencies at the edge, which explains rainbows & black holds, This is what it is. It travels straight, while rippling on gravity waves. Light is not a wave itself but it ripples when it encounters gravity waves while traveling straight. Gravity interacts with light. That's what a shimmer is.

Well there is kinda an answer to the question: Why the speed of light (c) is finite? Here it goes: If you go faster and faster time slows down. It's measurable! Time 'ticks' the fastest for you if there is no gravity or speed influence on you. (That's a part of Einstein's relativity.) As you approach c time slows down till it comes to a full stop at c. Length decreases too so at c the width/depth of the universe is 0 because you don't experience time it means that you don't need any time to travel through the universe. (Relativity kicks in: because for an outside observer these changes are happening to you.) In other words light needs 0s to take 0m. So if you were to travel faster than c the width/depth of the universe would flip to a negative value (not gonna happen bro XD) and time would flow backwards. (also not gonna happen XD) This brakes the rules of the universe and because light cannot travel faster than c, we assume that these rules CANNOT be broken. (This was the 'not so mind f***' explanation and it wasn't the most detailed too, however this topic has way more details worth mentioning. Maybe one day Kurzgesagt will make a video about it, WHO KNOWS?!)

If you analyze "motion", you find that it can not exist unless it is encapsulated within a finite. The finite is "c", the speed of light. In turn, if you were at true rest in space, then you will be moving across the dimension of time at c. Or. if you were able to be at true rest in time, then you would be moving across space at c.

Here, I have mentioned 2 different extremes. You immediately notice that if you gain in one, you lose in the other. Meaning, you can't have both extremes at the same time. You can't be moving across both space and time at c. Again, if you gain in one you lose in the other, thus for this to happen, motion must be encapsulated within a finite. That finite, is c.

We can deduce that the speed of light must be finite because of the simple observation that time exists, and we are not moving at that speed, therefore we have finite mass on top of experiencing time. The 2 infinities we talk about here cause something quite weird, they sum up to a finite answer, the light would reach the destination not instantly but it WILL reach the goal. So in a sense, light is infinitely fast in our world, it's just that stuff are infinitely far away from each other, and there are infinities bigger than infinities. Looks like it falls into the misconception "light is little sine waves." No, light doesn't move side to side. It was the Aether that did that, the transverse vibrations of the Luminiferous Aether. But there is no Aether, and no sideways wiggles. (Over a century, and still we haven't stamped out those sideways Aether vibrations!) Yes, the flux lines of light's EM fields do point sideways, but the waves don't look anything like wiggly worms. Here's a good MIT animation, basically of a single atom emitting light: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uNLj6NjQsbw Light is like an expanding onion.

Also, looks like you've picked up the misconception "light is really photons, not fields." That's the same mistake as thinking that it's really EM waves. For example, when atoms emit light, the light travels outwards in all directions, like expanding spherical ripples. Any animation which shows "bullets" or "wiggles" leaving an atom in a single direction is wrong. A "single photon" isn't like a flying sand-grain, it's more like an expanding onion miles across and miles thick.

Heh, describing quantum fields without totally misleading everyone is REALLY HARD. The first rule is, don't copy any other grade-school source, since most of them just copied others, which copied others, and all of them represent authors' misconceptions. Start from scratch, be creative in doing a proper job: one which lacks all the mistakes that others commonly make. (Look up SJ Gould and his "creeping fox terrier clone" effect, where pop science authors copy each other, producing all sorts of nonsensical weirdness.)

Also perhaps search out the paper "There are no particles, there are only fields." You might skip the math, but note the writer's complaints about pop science authors who don't seem to believe in EM waves. Also, ask physicists on forums how wide light's little sine-wave wiggles are. Answer: there is no width, any sine-wave is in a magnetic field intensity graph, but with no wiggles in space; light isn't like a vibrating string, instead it's like a magnet's field, only with expanding pulses (as in the linked animation.)

I'd like to point out something about c: it's not so much the "fastest speed" as the speed that everything moves at. Yes, you too. It makes sense when you think of the universe 4-dimensionally, with time as the last dimension. In three axes plus time (x, y, z, t), each has a "velocity" that adds up to c. You may have heard that relativity states that fast-moving objects experience time slower... this is why! Objects that are standing still (that is, x y and z are zero) have all of their speed in the time direction, experiencing time as fast as possible at a rate of one second per second. Meanwhile, light, which has all of its velocity in the spatial axes, has zero speed through time, and indeed light does not experience time, if light could experience things. Physically, the moment the light is created and destroyed are identical to that light. Everything else simply shows a mix of these values - as an object speeds up in spatial dimensions, it has to take some speed out of the time dimension and therefore moving slower. It just so happens that this velocity exchange becomes exponentially harder as objects get faster and only massless particles can transfer ALL of their velocity.

(PS - I omitted a lot of details hear for the sake of simplicity, and this isn't really how scientists talk about things anyway, it's just a conceptualization. One of the details I omitted was that the four dimensions don't actually sum to c via simple addition - it's a bit more complicated. It's more like an analogue of the distance formula, just like how moving at 1 m/s at 45 degrees is NOT the same as moving 1 m/s in the x and y dimensions (which would be ~1.414 m/s). I also neglected to mention the effects of gravity on time, and that there needs to be some reference for the speed in all four dimensions, which is pretty central to relativity.)

Some other information about the topics described in this video:
The type of decay in which an electron releases energy in the form of a photon to get to a lower energy state is called "Gamma Decay".
When the narrator says that "The photon is kind of a wave and kind of a particle, but that's a lie", he means that the photon cannot be a wave and a particle at the same time, though it can be a mixture of the two.
Particles that travel at the speed of light, such as gluons (Strong force carrier, binds quarks together within the hadron) and photons are called luxons. (particles with mass are called bradyons, and theoretical 'faster-than-light' particles are called tachyons.)
The photon is the gauge boson for the electromagnetic force, the same force that keeps an electron within the general area of an atom (the atom's nucleus is made up of protons, and opposite charges pull each other together).

I don't think the part about the speed limit of the universe "just happens to be" 'c' is genuine. At that speed, the changing electric wave induces the magnetic wave while the changing magnetic simultaneously induces the electric wave. Any faster or slower, one wave or the other annihilates it's counterpart. That's how it was so eloquently explained to me 20 years ago when I took physics 101 anyway. I guess it's not technically inaccurate to say "just happens to be" since there is not a good understanding of why this is the case at this particular speed, but there is definitely more to our understanding than "we don't know."

The way I saw it explained once, why light travels at c is, because the universe exists in space-time. Space and time are two dimensions you can move in. The more mass or energy (e=mc^2) something has, the more you'll move in the time dimension and the less mass something has the more you'll move in the space dimension. Since light has no mass it will move only in space.
This is why when you are close to a black hole (a shit ton of mass) time will go slower. Also why a neutrino (very small mass) will go almost at the speed of light.

This is great! I dunno if this counts as a smart answer to the question, but there is a kind of answer to why light has a finite speed. General relativity basically enforces the concept of causality, that effects always follow causes and never the other way around. Consequences of relativity are time dilation and length contraction with increasing speed. An infinite speed of light causes infinite time dilation and infinite length contraction, which makes the universe a single point in which time does not pass... not much of a universe!

"The smallest quantity of energy that can be transported" is pretty misleading. It implies an universal quantization of energy, which isn't really an accepted notion. Frequency and wavelength are, as far as we know, continuous quantities. This means you could in principle have a photon with an arbitrarily small energy, or two photons with an arbitrarily small energy difference.

Saying that light has no mass is wrong. It has the smallest amount of mass in all of our universe, but not none. (e=mc^2, which means that c^2=e/m). Mass comes from the speed itself (The Higgs Field, which explains how a small chunk of the mass is created, by the friction force of the moving particle) and energy is the wavelength.

Light

noun

make (something) start burning; ignite.

adjective
1.
having a considerable or sufficient amount of natural light; not dark.
2.
(of a colour) pale.
